G.L. c. 186, \u0000\u000b\u0000\u000b\u0.proposition: This action arises under the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment codified at G.L. c. 186, ���������� and related Massachusetts common law.

G.L. c. 218, \u0000\u000b\u0000\u000b\u0.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 218, �������������������������������������, the Springfield District Court has jurisdiction over this matter because the damages sought fall within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court and the claims arise under Massachusetts statutory and common law.

G.L. c. 223, \u0000\u000b\u0000\u000b\u0.proposition: Venue is proper in the Springfield District Court under G.L. c. 223, �� and G.L. c. 218, �� because the Premises are located in Springfield, Hampden County, and the causes of action arose within this Courts territorial jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 218, \u0000\u000b\u0000\u000b.proposition: Venue is proper in the Springfield District Court under G.L. c. 223, �� and G.L. c. 218, �� because the Premises are located in Springfield, Hampden County, and the causes of action arose within this Courts territorial jurisdiction.

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied into Plaintiffs tenancy by G.L. c. 186, �� and by common law.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly recognizes a covenant of quiet enjoyment and treats a failure to provide heat as a breach, but it does so in the context of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and related statutory case law. The court does not explicitly say that the covenant is implied into the tenancy by statute and by common law; rather, it discusses breach of quiet enjoyment and statutory liability together, leaving the precise doctrinal source (implied common‑law covenant versus statutory covenant) unstated. Thus it is helpful background authority on quiet enjoyment, but it does not squarely support the specific proposition as phrased.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season… seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’… and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See generally Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715-716 (1977), and cases cited. It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’ Blackett v. Olanoff, supra at 716.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied into Plaintiffs tenancy by G.L. c. 186, �� and by common law.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly assumes and applies an implied covenant (or warranty) of quiet enjoyment in the tenants’ leases, but it does not tie that implication to G.L. c. 186 or to any specific statutory subsection. The court treats the covenant as an implied term of the tenancy and discusses its scope and breach, citing only prior common-law cases, not the statute. Thus, the case supports the existence and breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment at common law, but not that it is implied "by G.L. c. 186" specifically.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge (lounge). … Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment sometimes have stated that the landlord must perform some act with the intent of depriving the tenant of the enjoyment and occupation of the whole or part of the leased premises.

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 19100 (1973)
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant, as landlord and owner, was responsible for maintaining the buildings electrical system and ensuring that the Apartment was fit for human habitation and reasonably suitable for the purposes for which it was rented, including use of both bedrooms.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly recognizes that, under the State Sanitary Code and related statutes, the *owner/landlord* bears the legal obligation to ensure that rented dwelling units meet minimum standards of fitness for human habitation, and that this obligation is implied into the rental agreement for the benefit of the tenant. While the excerpt does not specifically mention electrical systems or both bedrooms, it broadly places responsibility on the landlord to comply with code‑based habitability standards, which encompass building systems and habitability of the unit as rented. Thus it generally supports the proposition about the landlord’s responsibility for maintaining the premises in a habitable condition.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “Since 1960 dwelling units have been subject to the State Sanitary Code… It expressly provides that ‘[n]o person shall … let to another for occupancy any dwelling, dwelling unit, or rooming unit… which does not comply’ with its provisions… It expressly places the burden on the owner to comply with the prescribed minimum physical standards for rented dwelling units. … [T]he various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards….”

Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 168\u0.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant, as landlord and owner, was responsible for maintaining the buildings electrical system and ensuring that the Apartment was fit for human habitation and reasonably suitable for the purposes for which it was rented, including use of both bedrooms.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 168\u0.support_reasoning: The case holds that a Massachusetts landlord owes a duty of reasonable care in negligence to tenants’ guests regarding defects in the leased premises, and discusses statutory duties to correct unsafe conditions. It does not state that the landlord is responsible for maintaining the building’s electrical system, nor does it use or define a duty to ensure that the apartment (or its bedrooms) is fit for human habitation or reasonably suitable for its intended residential purposes—that language comes from the separate implied warranty of habitability line of cases, only referenced generally. Thus, the specific proposition about electrical maintenance and fitness for habitation is broader and more specific than what Young v. Garwacki actually decides.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 168\u0.relevant_excerpt: “Thus, at least to the extent required by the relevant housing and building codes, a landlord may be liable to his tenant for failing to maintain areas not under the landlord’s control. Today, we do away with the ancient law that bars a tenant’s guest from recovering compensation from a landlord for injuries caused by negligent maintenance of areas rented to the tenant… Henceforth, this basic principle of responsibility applies to Massachusetts landlords as well.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u000.proposition: Plaintiff promptly notified Defendant of the Electrical Defect and requested prompt repair, thereby giving Defendant actual notice of the condition.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u000.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses repeated tenant complaints about flooding and the landlord’s resulting notice of the flooding condition, but it does not involve or mention any ‘electrical defect,’ nor does it analyze legal sufficiency of notice for an electrical problem. The cited pages show that Solomon repeatedly called Gem about sewage flooding and that Gem sent cleanup crews, which could be used by analogy for notice, but the proposition as stated—actual notice of an electrical defect after prompt notice—is not what this case addresses. Therefore the citation does not accurately support that specific proposition.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u000.relevant_excerpt: “Solomon testified that she had repeatedly complained to Gem of floods. She stated that Gem on each occasion sent a cleanup crew to pump out the water, but never took permanent action. The jury, if they believed this testimony, could find that Gem knew or should have known that unless it fixed the porous wall flooding would occur, and that floods of sewage water were very likely to cause emotional harm.” (385 Mass. at 97)

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: Plaintiff promptly notified Defendant of the Electrical Defect and requested prompt repair, thereby giving Defendant actual notice of the condition.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns lead paint, quiet enjoyment, and the need for landlord notice and at least negligent conduct to establish a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14. It does not discuss any electrical defect, nor does it recite facts about a plaintiff promptly notifying a defendant of such a defect or requesting prompt repair. The proposition about actual notice of an electrical condition is therefore not supported by this case.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789… Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord… to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976,.raw_text: Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976, 97778 (1985)
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976,.proposition: The lack of electricity in the bedroom for approximately six weeks and counting constitutes a material deprivation of an essential service and renders that room effectively uninhabitable and unusable for its intended purpose.
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976,.support_reasoning: The opinion as excerpted does not mention any loss of electricity, let alone electricity to a bedroom for six weeks, nor does it analyze when loss of electricity renders a room uninhabitable. The habitability discussion concerns leaks, cockroaches, flooding, and an inadequate door, and the rent abatement is based on those conditions collectively. Accordingly, this case does not establish or discuss the specific principle about lack of electricity in a bedroom making it unusable for its intended purpose.
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976,.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that at the inception of LeClair’s tenancy there were a number of violations of the State Sanitary Code and that these problems had caused the prior tenant to vacate the premises after living there a few months. He also found that the landlord was repeatedly notified of the ongoing leaks and other problems on several occasions, and that, despite these complaints, the leakage and the roach problem remained uncorrected through April, 1982.”

Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443, 451.proposition: Defendants failure to remedy the Electrical Defect within a reasonable time after notice violates his duties under G.L. c. 186, �� and the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code.
Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443, 451.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses G.L. c. 186, § 19 and notes its negligence standard and notice requirement, but it does not hold that a landlord’s failure to remedy a code-related defect within a reasonable time after notice violates G.L. c. 186 or the State Sanitary Code. Instead, the court expressly declines to resolve issues about notice and reasonable time to repair, focusing on code violations existing at the time of letting and on common-law and implied warranty theories. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443, 451.relevant_excerpt: “Third, we need not now consider such matters as notice to the landlord of code violations arising after the letting and the time permitted the landlord to correct the violations. See 363 Mass. at 219. See G. L. c. 186, § 19, and Restatement (Second) of Property, Landlord & Tenant § 17.6 (1977), which prescribe a negligence standard. There was evidence warranting findings that the porch was part of the rented premises, and that at the time of the letting there were violations of the building and sanitary codes.”

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: The Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., requires landlords to maintain electrical facilities and fixtures in good repair and proper operating condition in compliance with applicable codes.

105 C.M.R. 410.351, 410.351(A).proposition: The Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., requires landlords to maintain electrical facilities and fixtures in good repair and proper operating condition in compliance with applicable codes.

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 199201 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Although the present action is brought solely under the covenant of quiet enjoyment, the Sanitary Code standards are relevant to whether Defendant has allowed conditions that substantially interfere with Plaintiffs tenancy and enjoyment of the Premises.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly ties the landlord’s common-law obligations (warranty/quiet enjoyment framework) to compliance with the State Sanitary Code and treats Code standards as the benchmark for determining whether there is a substantial interference with habitability. Although this case is framed as a warranty of habitability/rent abatement dispute rather than a covenant of quiet enjoyment action, its reasoning makes clear that Sanitary Code violations define when premises are not habitable and thus when the landlord has breached its obligations affecting the tenant’s use and enjoyment. Therefore, using it to support the relevance of Sanitary Code standards in a quiet enjoyment case is accurate by analogy.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for. … However, the State Sanitary Code, not such usage, provides the proper yardstick for measuring the landlord’s conduct. The Hemingway court removed the landlord’s duties under the Code from the realm of private ordering. … The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water.”

Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..raw_text: Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass. 708, 72021 (2002)
Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 186, ��, a landlord who breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment is liable for actual and consequential damages or for rentrelated damages (three months rent or three times actual damages, whichever is greater), as well as reasonable attorneys fees and costs.
Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion is a commercial lease case about adopting the rule of mutually dependent covenants and a tenant’s right to terminate and obtain relocation expenses. It does not interpret G.L. c. 186 or discuss statutory damages, multiple-of-rent remedies, or attorney’s fees for breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. Because the decision neither cites the statute nor sets out any rent-multiplier or fee-shifting scheme, it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..relevant_excerpt: We next consider whether the landlord’s actions regarding the leaky roof constituted a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment amounting to the constructive eviction of the tenant. Where there is a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, the tenant may raise constructive eviction as a defense to an action to recover rent. See Shindler v. Milden, 282 Mass. 32, 33-34 (1933). A constructive eviction is any “act of a permanent character, done by the landlord…with the intention and effect of depriving the tenant of the enjoyment of the premises…”
